This theorem states that for any type `Î±` equipped with a Bornology structure and assumed to be a Bounded Space, the filter of cobounded sets in this Bornology is the bottom filter. In other words, in a bounded space, there are no cobounded sets in the corresponding Bornology, or the concept of cobounded sets becomes trivial.

In other words, in a bounded space, there are no cobounded sets in the corresponding Bornology, or the concept of cobounded sets becomes trivial.

The theorem `StrictConvexOn.eq_of_isMinOn` states that for any strictly convex function `f` from a set `s` in a linearly ordered field `ğ•œ`, if the function `f` has a global minimum on `s` at two different points `x` and `y`, then `x` and `y` must be the same. This means a strictly convex function can have at most one global minimum.

name: StrictConvexOn.eq_of_isMinOn
docString: The theorem `StrictConvexOn.eq_of_isMinOn` states that for any strictly convex function `f` from a set `s` in a linearly ordered field `ğ•œ`, if the function `f` has a global minimum on `s` at two different points `x` and `y`, then `x` and `y` must be the same. This means a strictly convex function can have at most one global minimum.

A convenience function for `PreservesColimit`, which takes the functor as an explicit argument to

                {c : CategoryTheory.Limits.Cocone K} â†’

A convenience function for `PreservesColimit`, which takes the functor as an explicit argument to
